articles.title: Google quantum-proofs HTTPS by squeezing 2.5kB of data into 64-byte space - Ars Technica
articles.description: Merkle Tree Certificate support is already in Chrome. Soon, it will be everywhere.

articles.title: BMW Mistakenly Publishes The Names Of All 2027 Cars - Motor1.com
articles.description: BMW USA's website already shows the names of the 2027 model lineup, including an M2 xDrive and an M350 performance sedan based on the next-generation 3 Series.

articles.title: Porsche responds after Resident Evil fans claim Leon will definitely destroy his Porsche in Resident Evil Requiem - Dexerto
articles.description: Porsche’s Resident Evil Requiem collaboration has taken a turn, after fans reacted to the reveal trailer by joking that Leon S. Kennedy would destroy the Cayenne Turbo GT before the game even ends.

articles.title: A Dish of Neurons Playing DOOM Is the Wildest Thing I’ve Seen in Ages - Gizmodo
articles.description: Coming soon to a LAN party near you: a Petri dish.

articles.title: Where have the blade lights gone on the Galaxy Buds 4 Pro? - SamMobile
articles.description: Samsung introduced a substantial overhaul of the design of its wireless earbuds last year. The Galaxy Buds 3 Pro adopted a sleek look with stems that had a light strip in them. These blade lights, as they were called, were a significant departure from any des…

articles.title: Asus and Dell announce new mini PCs for Windows 365 - Notebookcheck
articles.description: Dell and Asus have announced new mini PCs intended for use with Windows 365. These systems will not power themselves, but will simply allow users to operate Windows running in the cloud.
